Meal delivery services will begin once again starting Tuesday, September 15 and will continue for the duration that the district is in full remote learning.

Due to the overwhelming interest in meal delivery, we will be delivering to elementary bus route stops and not directly to homes.

Buses will be arriving at each stop approximately 4.5 hours later than the normal route time with deliveries estimated to take place between 11:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. This decision was made to try to deliver meals when the majority of our students will be on their remote learning breaks.

Route times for delivery will be posted on KWRL’s website on Monday at www.kwrl.org.

Food service will continue to be offered in this fashion until our K-4 students can return to school for face-to-face instruction. At that time, we will reevaluate and develop a new plan for service.

For Monday, September 14, meals will be available for pickup at Woodland Middle School and Yale Elementary School from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m.

• This year (2020): $2.37 per $1,000 of assessed property value
• Next year (2021): $2.37 per $1,000 of assessed property value
• 2022: $2.36 per $1,000 of assessed property value

In a new text message, simply enter the type of help you need (police, fire, or medical) and address (including city). A 911 dispatcher will respond so stay with your phone to answer questions and follow instructions. Be sure to keep messages brief and use full words (no emojis, abbreviations, or text shorthand).

To learn more, you can download this informative flier: https://5il.co/crc2 or visit www.cowlitz911.org.

Woodland Public Schools’ students participated in the Great Washington ShakeOut on Thursday, October 17, 2019 at 10:17 a.m.
The Great ShakeOut is an organized earthquake drill to teach students what to do in the event of a seismic event. Students are taught to Drop, Cover, and Hold On.

When shaking starts, in most situations, everyone should drop where they are onto their hands and knees, crawl to a nearby desk or table (or an interior wall away from windows if no shelter is available) and then hold on to the shelter with one hand (or use both arms and hands to protect head and neck if no shelter is available).

More than 1.5 million participants registered to take part in 2019’s ShakeOut event! For more information, visit the ShakeOut website here: https://www.shakeout.org/washington/index.html

Woodland Middle School had a fire alarm go off shortly after 9 a.m. this morning. It was not a drill.

Staff and students practiced perfect evacuation techniques and exited the building promptly in an orderly fashion.

The alarm was silenced after approximately 4-5 minutes when the cause was determined to be a defective smoke detector and not an actual fire.

Students and staff returned to class, attendance was taken, and school resumed - a total disruption of less than 10 minutes.

Our diligent facilities team replaced the defective detector within 25 minutes. Typically, they can do the job much faster but the smoke detector in question was located 30 feet above the school's cafeteria!

Great job, everyone!

Woodland High School provided free health screenings for students thanks to a partnership with the Providence Heart Institute.

Since the free program’s inception six years ago, PHI has screened more than 26,000 youth. “Often there are no advance signs or symptoms of heart conditions with most routine physical not picking up defects,” explained Lydia. “An EKG is incredibly effective at uncovering signs of heart irregularities, however it’s a test not typically performed in ‘well-child’ checks or even sports physicals.”

Serious health issues were found in more than 6% of the screened students – 1,336 students so far – and those students received further follow-up and treatment thanks to the results of their health screening. “We’re just as concerned about students who are less active as we are about student athletes,” said Lydia. “This service offers another level of health protection for our youngest population, helping them identify potentially life-threatening conditions and beginning treatment before they become serious.”

To read the entire story, click here: http://bit.ly/2q2O9ol

All children up to 18 years old can eat breakfast from 8:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and lunch from 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. free-of-charge at the Woodland Middle School Commons. Adult meal prices are $2.50 for breakfast and $3.50 for lunch.

Please note, the program is closed on July 4, 2018.

For more information, call Stacy Brown, Woodland Public Schools Business Manager, at (360) 841-2715.

For more information: https://goo.gl/Nj4dJo

Today, Friday, June 22, is the last day of school for the 2017-2018 school year.

We had a great year with all of our students and will miss you over the summer vacation.

Stay tuned to Facebook, Twitter and the district website (www.woodlandschools.org) throughout the summer for news, events and other updates from your Woodland Public Schools.

The new school year will be here before you know it with our first day of school on Tuesday, August 28.

We wish all of our students a happy, fun and safe summer! Don’t forget to keep learning!

Save the date for Back to School Bash 2018!

Woodland Public Schools invites you to attend the 2018 Back to School Bash on Saturday, August 18 from 3:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. at Woodland High School.

The Back to School Bash is open to ALL students of ALL ages attending Woodland, La Center and Kalama schools and features FREE backpacks with school supplies for students as well as games, bounce houses, prizes and food!

We hope to see you Saturday, August 18 from 3:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. at Woodland High School located at 1500 Dike Access Road in Woodland for this year’s Back to School Bash! It will be fun for the entire family!

This event is possible thanks to the generous donations made by Woodland Public Schools with sponsorship from local churches and communities.

Woodland Public Schools celebrated its largest graduating class, the Class of 2018, with a Senior Breakfast, Graduate Parade and Commencement Ceremony!

Woodland High School celebrated its largest graduating class with 155 graduates in a series of events culminating in the Commencement Ceremony on Friday, June 15. Graduates took part in a Senior Breakfast, paraded through district schools in the Parade of Graduates, and concluded by walking in the 110th Annual Commencement to receive their diplomas.
